utterances: As other carmakers sped into the SUV market, Isuzu lost its position at the forefront.
Last year the company sold just 7,000 vehicles in the U.S.
Isuzu says its move to exit the American passenger market starting next year is the result of General Motors' decision to stop producing the two models it makes for Isuzu.
Astronauts often say that one of the best things about being in space is looking down at the beautiful blue Earth.
Well, now the International Space Station is about to get what NASA is calling a room with a view.
It's a kind of observation tower that will give astronauts a window on the world unlike any other in space.
NPR's Nell Greenfieldboyce reports.
Right now, astronauts on board the station can peer out through small portholes.
The biggest, best window is in the U.S.
Destiny Lab.
It's a porthole 20 inches across.
But this Sunday morning, space shuttle Endeavour is scheduled to blast off on a mission to deliver a new room to the station.
This room will have a 360-degree bay window called the cupola.
It has seven windows, so astronauts can float inside and be surrounded by panoramic views.
Terry Virts will be a first-time space flyer on the Endeavour mission.

The one thing that I'm really looking forward to, and I know all my crewmates are also, is getting a chance to look out of the cupola, with the seven windows and the view that we're going to get there.
That's going to be really special to see that view of the Earth and of space and that's going to be fun.
Technically, the new windows aren't for fun.
They'll help astronauts orchestrate outside work, things like spacewalks, robotic arm operations, and docking spaceships.

And the windows do have aluminum shutters that will often be closed, that's to keep them from being hit by tiny bits of flying space rock or space junk - even though the tough windows already are several panes thick.
Still, the astronauts can't wait to get the new room all installed and finally open those shutters for the first time.
Kay Hire is an astronaut going up on Endeavour.
We will definitely be bringing along some still cameras as well as video cameras to try to capture those views as best we can to share with you.
But, she says, she can guarantee those photos won't be able to convey exactly what it's like to see the vast expanse of earth and space spread out all around.
Nell Greenfieldboyce, NPR News.
And for more now on the off-year elections and what they tell us about the current political landscape, we turn to our political watchers to grab some insight.
And this week, we're joined by David Brooks of the New York Times and Cynthia Tucker, columnist with the Atlanta Journal-Constitution.
Welcome to both of you.
Good to be here.
Thank you.
So, beyond that seat in New Jersey and the governor's race in Virginia, what's at stake for both parties?
Cynthia, I'm going to begin with you.
So, it might be better to use your offspring for campaign purpose Number Two: Talk to other young people.
That's what the Huntsman daughters say is their main job.
Other students at Virginia Tech on Monday morning included Erin Peterson.
She was a freshman on the basketball team.
She'd been a high school star in Chantilly, Virginia, where her coach was Patrick Pat Deegan.
If the team needed some points, Erin put the points in.
If the team needed some rebounds, Erin would go get that rebound.
If the team needed, you know, someone to boost up everyone else, Erin would do that as well.
Erin Peterson was killed on Monday, along with Reema Samaha.
She loved to dance.
She was part of Virginia Tech's contemporary dance ensemble and she practiced for hours each week with Talia Routneck(ph).
I know that she performed in a number of different dance groups, one of which is ours, another if which is a ballet dancing group that she ran on campus.
She was one of the most wonderful people to be around, one of the most beautiful people - inside and out - that I've ever met.
Another person at Virginia Tech on Monday morning was Kevin Granada.
He was a professor in a department headed by Ishwar Puri.
Kevin grew up in the United States, I believe in Ohio.
He was in the military and then he did some orthopedics work in British hospitals, and then he found the call to serve to be a researcher and to serve higher education and came to Virginia Tech.
Kevin Granata became a top researcher on cerebral palsy before he was killed on Monday.
His fellow professors included Liviu Librescu.
He was a Holocaust survivor.
He was also survived life in communist Romania before slipping away to research in the West.
He was a giant.
His work has helped us make better airplanes, better composite materials.
Both Liviu and Kevin were dedicated teachers.
They mentored large numbers of students.
I received messages from all over the world from their Ph.D. students who are professors.
According to media reports, in the last moments of his life, Liviu Librescu tried to stop the shooter from entering a classroom.
He threw himself against the door.
Those are some of Monday's victims.
And NPR will remember more through the day.
You can read profiles of the victims at npr.org.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Andrea Seabrook.
Super Tuesday is still reverberating in American politics, but there are new results today from four more states.
The Kansas Republican caucuses went overwhelmingly for Mike Huckabee.
Kansan's seem to reject the notion that John McCain has the race all sewn up.
Both parties compete in caucuses in Washington and primaries in Louisiana today.
And Democrats caucus in Nebraska.
Joining me here in the studio is NPR senior Washington editor Ron Elving.
Ron, let's start with what we know at this point.
Kansas has gone for Huckabee.
What are the numbers and was this a surprise?
It was not a huge surprise, Andrea, because Kansas has a very large and active evangelical community within its Republican Party.
It's been doing battle with a more, if you will, old guard or establishment Republican faction within the state party for many years.
And today there was very small turnout in Kansas.
Only about 20,000 people appear to have voted.
And so with a little less than 12,000 votes, Mike Huckabee has 60 percent of the vote.
And that's going to be good for all 36 delegates from Kansas to the Republican convention for Mike Huckabee.
Interesting there.
And so what do we know about Nebraska at this point, Ron?
We don't know much yet, and it's going to be a little while before we do get the final results from Nebraska.
But there are 24 delegates to the Democratic convention at stake there today.
Nebraska is not having a Republican event today.
And there we only know that in Nebraska's big city - Omaha - there was a huge rally yesterday for Barack Obama, which resulted in the morning paper today having the headline Obamaha.
Obamaha.
Exactly.
And we understand there were huge turnouts today for the precinct caucuses in the city of Omaha where Barack Obama is thought to be strongest.
Hmm.
Okay.
So we'll wait for results there.
What about the other events today?
Both parties compete in Washington and Louisiana.
Do we have any idea about those?
We don't at this point.
And the Washington caucuses, generally speaking, are thought to have been concluded.
Although they're being conducted in hundreds of sites around the state and we can't say for sure they're all finished yet.
But they're gathering the results there at this point.
In the past this is an event that drew about 100,000 people each four years.
This year they're thinking 250,000 or more.
Every caucus site we've heard from has huge overflow.
And in Louisiana maybe not so much.

There the primary that they're having today in both parties does not seem to have attracted anywhere near the same level of interest, and the turnout there is relatively small compared to the rest of the country this winter.
So quickly, Ron Elving, the national scoreboard, what will this look like at the end of today?
In just the last ten seconds we have.
Slight improvement for Mike Huckabee, but he's not going to be the nominee of the Republican Party.
And on the Democratic side, probably a gain overall for Barack Obama.
We'll see if it brings him even.
Okay.
NPR's senior Washington editor, Ron Elving.
Our gadgets just keep getting smaller and smaller.

Researchers at the University of California, Berkeley, have developed a very tiny radio.
It's barely a collection of atoms - so small that it would take 10,000 of them to span a diameter of a single human hair.
The Berkeley lab team listened to the Beach Boys on it as they watched their contraption the only way they could - through a high-powered electron microscope.
I spoke with Alex Zettl, who led that team.
This microscopic radio is what's called a carbon nanotube - a needle which vibrates at the exact frequency of the station you're trying to listen to.
